topic.title: HPE Helion OpenStack 2.0: Adding an Object Storage Daemon (OSD) Node

body.p: The page describes how to add a new object storage daemon (OSD) node to an existing Ceph cluster.

p.b: To Add a New OSD Node

body.p:
Perform the following steps to add a new OSD node to an existing Ceph cluster:
Login to the lifecycle manager.
Edit the ~/helion/my_cloud/definition/data/servers.yml file to define a new OSD node:- id: osd4 ip-addr: 192.168.10.11 role: OSD-ROLE server-group: RACK3 nic-mapping: MY-2PORT-SERVER mac-addr: 8b:f6:9e:ca:3b:7a ilo-ip: 192.168.9.11 ilo-password: password ilo-user: adminEnter the appropriate values in the above sample as per your environment for the server being added.
Commit your configuration to the local Git repository (for instructions, see ): cd ~/helion/hos/ansible git add -A git commit -m "Added OSD node <node-id>"Replace the <node-id> in the commit message with appropriate value (example: con-004).
Run the following command:cd ~/helion/hos/ansible/ ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost cobbler-deploy.yml
Reimage all the nodes using PXE:ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost bm-reimage.yml
Run the Configuration Processor:ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml
Use the playbook below to create a deployment directory: ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost ready-deployment.yml
Run the following commands:
cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts guard-deployment.yml ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts osconfig-run.yml ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts ceph-deploy.yml
The new OSD node is deployed in an existing Ceph cluster.
To Verify the Newly Added OSD Node
From the lifecycle manager, run the following command:$ceph --cluster ceph osd tree
If the Ceph cluster name is different than the default (i.e. ceph), you need to modify the above command accordingly.
When you run the above command, if the OSD node has been successfully added to the existing Ceph cluster, the hostname of the newly added OSD should appear in the output.
